greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: Row products give A027642.
comment: Except for the first column, the n-th prime number appears in every A006093(n)-th row, beginning at the A000040(n)-th row, in the n-th column.
link: Michel Marcus, Rows n=0..100 of triangle, flattened
formula: T(n,k) = A000040(k) if A027642(n) mod A000040(k) = 0, 1 otherwise.
example: Row products of the first few rows are:
maple: seq(seq(T(n, k), k=1..n+1), n=0..20);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Aug 27 2017
mathematica: Table[With[{p = Prime@ k}, p Boole[Divisible[Denominator@ BernoulliB[n - 1], p]]] /. 0 -> 1, {n, 14}, {k, n}] // Flatten (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Aug 27 2017 *)
program: (PARI) tabl(nn) = {for (n=0, nn, dbn = denominator(bernfrac(n)); for (k=1, n+1, if (! (dbn % prime(k)), w = prime(k), w = 1); print1(w, ", "); ); print; ); } \\ _Michel Marcus_, Aug 27 2017
results.author: _Mats Granvik_, Mar 08 2008
ext: Offset corrected by _Alois P. Heinz_, Aug 27 2017
